Increased bus service proposed
By BOB BENJAMIN
Two graduate student
members of the Homewood
Advisory Committee (HAC)have
Proposed a major expansion of
the University's intercampus
transportation system.
John Caldwell and Doug
Costain are currently working to
increase the frequency of the
buses between the Homewood
campus and the Medical School
and to establish a regular
schedule of buses to SAIS and
the Library of Congress in
Washington.
The present system provides
for a bus to leave the Homewood
campus for the Medical School
every hour on the hour.
Caldwell has, proposed that
this be increased to a bus leaving
each location every half hour
from 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. and
hourly service from 5:30p.m. to
midnight. He also wants
departures to be 10 minutes after
the hour and half hour to better
coincide with actual class times
and that stops and pickup be
made at several of the important

buildings in the Schools of
Hygiene and Medicine.
"The purpose of the service is
to keep people from having to
park and walk long distances.
This is particularly important at
night and I guess you have to be
a girl to really understand."
He expressed hope that the
busses will stop at more locations
and will allow people to wait
inside the buildings to decrease
the chances of muggings.
Caldwell has received support
for his proposals from student
organizations at both the Medical
School and School of Hygiene.
Currently the only
University -operated
transportation service to
Washington is the weekly van
used by the library to pick up
inter-library loan books from the
Library of Congress and SAIS.
Students are permitted to ride
in the van, but must sign up in
advance and the list usually
contains more names than the
maximum capacity of the van,
which is seven.

By A. P. SMITHWICK
Heroin if administered with
sterile paraphenalia can be used
throughout life without- much
harm, two Hopkins doctors
agreed last night.
Dr. Torrey Brown, the director
of the Drug Abuse Center at
Johns Hopkins Hospital and Dr.
Soloman Snyder, a Professor of

T herapeutics at the Johns
Hopkins School of Medicine,
Spoke before a drug symposium
at the Johns Hopkins School of
HYgiene.
According to Brown, the
addict's problems develop not
from heroin itself but from the
sYtinges and needles. If caught

with a syringe or needle, one is
considered as guilty as with
heroin. Commented Brown,
"Narcotics pushers ought to be
required to push clean
paraphenalia and equipment."
• Snyder objected that the
government is now making it
very difficult for a researcher to
get hold of drugs. He humorously
